awd_titl_txt: Innovating Infrastructure: A new platform for studying dynamic regional economies
awd_abstract_narration:
This research focuses on geographically-defined economic regions in order to understand why some regions thrive while others stagnate. The key barrier to such research is the lack of detailed, time-series data at the individual, firm, and institutional level.  Over the past 6 years, the researchers have acquired such data on over 4200 technology firms in the Research Triangle Park region of North Carolina and they are now able to examine the spatial and temporal relationships between economic entities and uncover the drivers of regional economic outcomes.

The researchers have developed a relational database and tool sets that enables the organization, curation, and search of this data. They are now extending this solution with a cyberinfrastructure that manages diverse types of economic data, aids in integration of newer data, and powers new approaches for analysis and visualization of geo-spatial-temporal data, while addressing privacy and security concerns. Through this new cyberinfrastructure, a community of interdisciplinary scholars are able to have access to the data and tools on regional economics. Likewise, policy makers and economic practitioners could have access to reporting tools that provide greater detail than is available today. Going forward, the developed cyberinfrastructure provides both a framework and needed solutions to power other regional research systems and thus further extend our knowledge of regional economics.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

por.por_cntn:
The Innovating Infrastructure project contributed to advancing ongoing research into the factors that drive success, stagnation, and failure of regional economics. A key outcome of this project is that we now have a high quality database which continues to be populated by student curators, along with the tools to access and visualize the data.  The system is highly flexible which will allow us to adapt to future needs.  At the same time, the system is robust enough that maintenance costs are very low and the students and researchers using the system are able to query for needed data and generate reports without a need for involving the system developers. The cyberinfrastructure is mature and in production use by the research team, and has been deployed for use by another group (Chattanooga) and is being investigated by other groups. 

Within the scope of this project, students successfully entered micro-level data about companies, company founders, founders work and educational history, company events (e.g., IPO, closure, creation), patents, products, and funding events (e.g., Series 1 investment) through a data entry website that enforces data quality constraints and captures sources of microlevel data. As of the project’s completion, the database now contains over 5,000 companies. Further, the microlevel data can be assessed programmatically or through on-line web reports with the ability to restrict access based on users or user groups. The advanced visualizations are web-based and access the database through the programmatic API, so visualizations are now live web-based applications, as opposed to static snapshots (see attached examples).

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2017
Modified by: Nichola J Lowe
